an4.178:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.178:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:1.3.eng: Take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:1.4.eng: They focus on the cessation of substantial reality,

an4.178:1.5.pli: Tassa sakkāyanirodhaṃ manasi karoto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
an4.178:1.5.eng: but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

an4.178:1.6.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na sakkāyanirodho pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:1.6.eng: You wouldn’t expect that mendicant to realize the cessation of substantial reality.

an4.178:1.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso lepagatena hatthena sākhaṃ gaṇheyya, tassa so hattho sajjeyyapi gaṇheyyapi bajjheyyapi;
an4.178:1.7.eng: Suppose a person were to grab a branch with a glue-smeared hand. Their hand would stick, hold, and bind to it.

an4.178:1.8.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:1.8.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:1.9.eng: They focus on the cessation of substantial reality,

an4.178:1.10.pli: Tassa sakkāyanirodhaṃ manasi karoto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
an4.178:1.10.eng: but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

an4.178:1.11.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na sakkāyanirodho pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:1.11.eng: You wouldn’t expect that mendicant to realize the cessation of substantial reality.

an4.178:2.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:2.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:2.2.eng: They focus on the cessation of substantial reality,

an4.178:2.3.pli: Tassa sakkāyanirodhaṃ manasi karoto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
an4.178:2.3.eng: and on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

an4.178:2.4.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sakkāyanirodho pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:2.4.eng: You would expect that mendicant to realize the cessation of substantial reality.

an4.178:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso suddhena hatthena sākhaṃ gaṇheyya, tassa so hattho neva sajjeyya na gaṇheyya na bajjheyya;
an4.178:2.5.eng: Suppose a person were to grab a branch with a clean hand. Their hand wouldn’t stick, hold, or bind to it.

an4.178:2.6.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:2.6.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:2.7.eng: They focus on the cessation of substantial reality,

an4.178:2.8.pli: Tassa sakkāyanirodhaṃ manasi karoto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
an4.178:2.8.eng: and on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

an4.178:2.9.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sakkāyanirodho pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:2.9.eng: You would expect that mendicant to realize the cessation of substantial reality.

an4.178:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:3.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:3.3.pli: Tassa avijjāppabhedaṃ manasi karoto avijjāppabhede cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
an4.178:3.3.eng: but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

an4.178:3.4.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na avijjāppabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:3.4.eng: You wouldn’t expect that mendicant to smash ignorance.

an4.178:3.5.eng: Suppose there was a billabong that had been stagnant for many years.

an4.178:3.6.pli: Tassā puriso yāni ceva āyamukhāni tāni pidaheyya, yāni ca apāyamukhāni tāni vivareyya, devo ca na sammā dhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya.
an4.178:3.6.eng: And someone was to close off the inlets and open up the drains, and the heavens didn’t provide enough rain.

an4.178:3.7.pli: Evañhi tassā, bhikkhave, jambāliyā na āḷippabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:3.7.eng: You wouldn’t expect that billabong to break its banks.

an4.178:3.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:3.8.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a certain peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:3.10.pli: Tassa avijjāppabhedaṃ manasi karoto avijjāppabhede cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
an4.178:3.10.eng: but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

an4.178:3.11.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na avijjāppabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:3.11.eng: You wouldn’t expect that mendicant to smash ignorance.

an4.178:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:4.1.eng: Next, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:4.3.pli: Tassa avijjāppabhedaṃ manasi karoto avijjāppabhede cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
an4.178:4.3.eng: and on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

an4.178:4.4.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjāppabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:4.4.eng: You would expect that mendicant to smash ignorance.

an4.178:4.5.eng: Suppose there was a billabong that had been stagnant for many years.

an4.178:4.6.pli: Tassā puriso yāni ceva āyamukhāni tāni vivareyya, yāni ca apāyamukhāni tāni pidaheyya, devo ca sammā dhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya.
an4.178:4.6.eng: And someone was to open up the inlets and close off the drains, and the heavens provided plenty of rain.

an4.178:4.7.pli: Evañhi tassā, bhikkhave, jambāliyā āḷippabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:4.7.eng: You would expect that billabong to break its banks.

an4.178:4.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ santaṃ cetovimuttiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.178:4.8.eng: In the same way, take a mendicant who enters and remains in a certain peaceful release of the heart.

an4.178:4.10.pli: Tassa avijjāppabhedaṃ manasi karoto avijjāppabhede cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati adhimuccati.
an4.178:4.10.eng: and on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

an4.178:4.11.pli: Tassa kho evaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjāppabhedo pāṭikaṅkho.
an4.178:4.11.eng: You would expect that mendicant to smash ignorance.

an4.178:4.12.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.178:4.12.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.”

an4.179:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.179:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.179:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.179:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Ānanda sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:

an4.179:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, hetu ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme na parinibbāyantī”ti?
an4.179:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, Reverend Sāriputta, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life?”

an4.179:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso ānanda, sattā imā hānabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, imā ṭhitibhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, imā visesabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, imā nibbedhabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
an4.179:2.1.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, it’s because some sentient beings don’t really understand which perceptions make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration.

an4.179:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme na parinibbāyantī”ti.
an4.179:2.2.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in this very life.”

an4.179:3.1.pli: “Ko panāvuso sāriputta, hetu ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti?
an4.179:3.1.eng: “What is the cause, Reverend Sāriputta, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life?”

an4.179:3.2.pli: “Idhāvuso ānanda, sattā imā hānabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, imā ṭhitibhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, imā visesabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, imā nibbedhabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
an4.179:3.2.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, it’s because some sentient beings truly understand which perceptions make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration.

an4.179:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso ānanda, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyantī”ti.
an4.179:3.3.eng: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in this very life.”

an4.18:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of making unprejudiced decisions.

an4.18:1.3.pli: Na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati—
an4.18:1.3.eng: Making decisions unprejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an4.18:1.4.eng: These are the four ways of making unprejudiced decisions.

an4.18:2.1.eng: If you don’t act against the teaching

an4.18:2.2.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, and stupidity,

an4.18:2.4.eng: like the moon in the waxing fortnight.”

an4.180:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhoganagare viharati ānandacetiye.
an4.180:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near the Bhoga City, at the Ānanda Shrine.

an4.180:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an4.180:1.6.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the four great references.

an4.180:1.7.pli: taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an4.180:1.7.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an4.180:1.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an4.180:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, what are the four great references?

an4.180:2.3.pli: ‘sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
an4.180:2.3.eng: ‘Reverend, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an4.180:2.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:2.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:2.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
an4.180:2.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

an4.180:2.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte otāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
an4.180:2.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

an4.180:2.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte otāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni na ceva sutte otaranti na vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.180:2.7.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

an4.180:2.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa;
an4.180:2.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an4.180:2.9.eng: It has been incorrectly memorized by that mendicant.’

an4.180:2.10.eng: And so you should discard it.

an4.180:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

an4.180:3.2.pli: ‘sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
an4.180:3.2.eng: ‘Reverend, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an4.180:3.3.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:3.3.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:3.4.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
an4.180:3.4.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

an4.180:3.5.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte otāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
an4.180:3.5.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

an4.180:3.6.eng: If they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

an4.180:3.7.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an4.180:3.8.eng: It has been correctly memorized by that mendicant.’

an4.180:3.9.eng: You should remember it. This is the first great reference.

an4.180:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

an4.180:4.2.pli: ‘asukasmiṃ nāma āvāse saṅgho viharati sathero sapāmokkho.
an4.180:4.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery lives a Saṅgha with seniors and leaders.

an4.180:4.3.pli: Tassa me saṅghassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
an4.180:4.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of that Saṅgha:

an4.180:4.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:4.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:6.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery there are several senior mendicants who are very learned, inheritors of the heritage, who remember the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines.

an4.180:7.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:7.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the monastic law, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:7.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
an4.180:7.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

an4.180:7.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte otāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
an4.180:7.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

an4.180:7.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte otāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni sutte ceva otaranti vinaye ca sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.180:7.7.eng: If they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

an4.180:7.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa;
an4.180:7.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an4.180:7.9.eng: It has been correctly memorized by those senior mendicants.’

an4.180:7.10.eng: You should remember it. This is the third great reference.

an4.180:8.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

an4.180:8.2.pli: ‘asukasmiṃ nāma āvāse eko thero bhikkhu viharati bahussuto āgatāgamo dhammadharo vinayadharo mātikādharo.
an4.180:8.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery there is a single senior mendicant who is very learned, an inheritor of the heritage, who has memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines.

an4.180:8.3.pli: Tassa me therassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
an4.180:8.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of that senior mendicant:

an4.180:8.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:8.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:8.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
an4.180:8.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

an4.180:8.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte otāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
an4.180:8.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

an4.180:8.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte otāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni na ceva sutte otaranti na vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.180:8.7.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

an4.180:8.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa;
an4.180:8.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an4.180:8.9.eng: It has been incorrectly memorized by that senior mendicant.’

an4.180:8.10.eng: And so you should discard it.

an4.180:9.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

an4.180:9.2.pli: ‘asukasmiṃ nāma āvāse eko thero bhikkhu viharati bahussuto āgatāgamo dhammadharo vinayadharo mātikādharo.
an4.180:9.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery there is a single senior mendicant who is very learned, an inheritor of the heritage, who has memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines.

an4.180:9.3.pli: Tassa me therassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
an4.180:9.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of that senior mendicant:

an4.180:9.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo, idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
an4.180:9.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

an4.180:9.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
an4.180:9.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

an4.180:9.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte otāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
an4.180:9.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

an4.180:9.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte otāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni sutte ceva otaranti vinaye ca sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
an4.180:9.7.eng: If they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

an4.180:9.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa;
an4.180:9.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

an4.180:9.9.eng: It has been correctly memorized by that senior mendicant.’

an4.180:9.10.eng: You should remember it. This is the fourth great reference.

an4.180:9.11.eng: These are the four great references.”

an4.181:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato yodhājīvo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.181:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a warrior with four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.181:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo ṭhānakusalo ca hoti, dūrepātī ca, akkhaṇavedhī ca, mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
an4.181:1.3.eng: He’s skilled in the basics, a long-distance shooter, a marksman, one who shatters large objects.

an4.181:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgato yodhājīvo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.181:1.4.eng: A warrior with these four factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.181:1.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.181:1.5.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with four qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.181:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ṭhānakusalo ca hoti, dūrepātī ca, akkhaṇavedhī ca, mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
an4.181:1.7.eng: He’s skilled in the basics, a long-distance shooter, a marksman, one who shatters large objects.

an4.181:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in the basics?

an4.181:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an4.181:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an4.181:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ṭhānakusalo hoti.
an4.181:2.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in the basics.

an4.181:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a long-distance shooter?

an4.181:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an4.181:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.181:3.3.eng: They truly see any kind of feeling …

an4.181:3.6.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an4.181:3.6.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.181:3.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dūrepātī hoti.
an4.181:3.7.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a long-distance shooter.

an4.181:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a marksman?

an4.181:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.181:4.2.eng: It’s when they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.181:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhaṇavedhī hoti.
an4.181:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a marksman.

an4.181:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahato kāyassa padāletā hoti?
an4.181:5.1.eng: And how does a mendicant shatter large objects?

an4.181:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahantaṃ avijjākkhandhaṃ padāletā.
an4.181:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant shatters the great mass of ignorance.

an4.181:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahato kāyassa padāletā hoti.
an4.181:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant shatters large objects.

an4.181:5.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an4.181:5.4.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities … is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an4.182:1.1.eng: “There are four things that no-one can guarantee—

an4.182:1.2.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ.
an4.182:1.2.eng: not an ascetic, a brahmin, a god, a Māra, a divinity, or anyone in the world.

an4.182:2.2.eng: No-one can guarantee that someone liable to old age will not grow old.

an4.182:2.3.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ;

an4.182:2.4.eng: No-one can guarantee that someone liable to sickness will not get sick.

an4.182:2.5.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ;

an4.182:2.6.eng: No-one can guarantee that someone liable to death will not die.

an4.182:2.7.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ;

an4.182:2.8.pli: ‘yāni kho pana tāni pubbe attanā katāni pāpakāni kammāni saṅkilesikāni ponobhavikāni sadarāni dukkhavipākāni āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇikāni, tesaṃ vipāko mā nibbattī’ti natthi koci pāṭibhogo—
an4.182:2.8.eng: No-one can guarantee that the bad deeds done in past lives—corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—will not produce their result.

an4.182:2.9.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ.

an4.182:3.1.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ natthi koci pāṭibhogo—
an4.182:3.1.eng: These are the four things that no-one can guarantee—

an4.182:3.2.pli: samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmin”ti.
an4.182:3.2.eng: not an ascetic, a brahmin, a god, a Māra, a divinity, or anyone in the world.”

an4.183:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
an4.183:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

an4.183:1.2.pli: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.183:1.2.eng: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, a chief minister of Magadha, went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.183:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.183:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an4.183:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:

an4.183:2.2.eng: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve seen, saying:

an4.183:2.3.pli: evaṃ me diṭṭhanti, natthi tato doso;

an4.183:2.4.eng: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve heard, saying:

an4.183:2.5.pli: evaṃ me sutanti, natthi tato doso;

an4.183:2.6.eng: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve thought, saying:

an4.183:2.7.pli: evaṃ me mutanti, natthi tato doso;

an4.183:2.8.eng: There’s nothing wrong with talking about what you’ve known, saying:

an4.183:2.9.pli: evaṃ me viññātanti, natthi tato doso’”ti.

an4.183:3.1.eng: “Brahmin, I don’t say you should talk about everything you see, hear, think, and know.

an4.183:3.2.pli: na panāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ diṭṭhaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;
an4.183:3.2.eng: But I also don’t say you should talk about nothing you see, hear, think, and know.

an4.183:3.3.pli: nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ sutaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;

an4.183:3.4.pli: na panāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ sutaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;

an4.183:3.5.pli: nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ mutaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;

an4.183:3.6.pli: na panāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ mutaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;

an4.183:3.7.pli: nāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ viññātaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi;

an4.183:3.8.pli: na panāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sabbaṃ viññātaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:4.1.pli: Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, diṭṭhaṃ bhāsato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ diṭṭhaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.
an4.183:4.1.eng: When talking about certain things you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known, unskillful qualities grow while skillful qualities decline. I say that you shouldn’t talk about those things.

an4.183:4.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, brāhmaṇa, diṭṭhaṃ abhāsato kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ diṭṭhaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.
an4.183:4.2.eng: When talking about other things you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known, unskillful qualities decline while skillful qualities grow. I say that you should talk about those things.”

an4.183:5.1.pli: Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ bhāsato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ sutaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:5.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ abhāsato kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ sutaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:6.1.pli: Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, mutaṃ bhāsato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ mutaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:6.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, brāhmaṇa, mutaṃ abhāsato kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ mutaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:7.1.pli: Yañhi, brāhmaṇa, viññātaṃ bhāsato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṃ viññātaṃ na bhāsitabbanti vadāmi.

an4.183:7.2.pli: Yañca khvassa, brāhmaṇa, viññātaṃ abhāsato kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṃ viññātaṃ bhāsitabbanti vadāmī”ti.

an4.183:8.1.pli: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
an4.183:8.1.eng: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.
